results.title: Unreserved : stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve
results.brief_description:
Unreserved : Stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve is the culmination of a community arts project involving local residents and some of Melbourne’s up and coming designers. Based on oral histories collected from local residents who have a connection with this historic site, a series of animations have been produced recreating some of the unique stories of this site.
Truganina Explosives Reserve, one of Altona’s last intact historic sites, is located 26 kilometres west of the city, and nine kilometres from Williamstown on the shores of Port Phillip Bay. The reserve was established by the State Government in 1901 for the storage and handling of commercial explosives. After its closure in 1962, the reserve lay dormant for more than 25 years, protected from the outside world by the two and a half metre high galvanised fence.
In the 1990s, the reserve became the site of an intense community battle aimed at saving the site from redevelopment. The community embarked on a quest to save one of the western suburbs’ most significant historical and environmental locations, the site of an important early Australian industry.

results.title: [The Dead Table]
results.brief_description: There’s never been any explosions at the Truganina Explosives Reserve in Altona, but accidents, well that’s another story. As a child, Alan Dyall’s father worked at the reserve in Melbourne’s west. One of his many jobs involved ‘laying out in the lighters’, a lighter being a boat that carried explosives from Williamstown to the steamship. If the steamship hadn’t yet arrived, it was his job to sleep on board until it did. This is a childhood of tales lovingly recalled and the amazing story of his father’s near fatal accident.

results.title: Staying Connected
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet Stephen Giles, a Caramut local, who now lives and works in the city but remains connected to the town through the Caramut Football Club, which he started playing for when he was 8 years old. He is now a patron of the club, just like his father was, and has helped the community to keep it alive, recognising its importance to the locals. He even puts on the footy boots again to play in the Seniors League.

results.title: Looking Back
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Three locals talk about personal histories in the small town of Caramut in regional Victoria. Take a trip down memory lane with Patricia Giles as she talks about soldier settlement and how the town has changed over the years. Tom and Dan Dickson look back on their family history and give us a tour of the town, including a stone bridge their great grandfather built that still stands in Caramut today.

results.title: Tales from Caramut Footy
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: The Caramut Football Club brings the locals together and keeps the community spirit alive. Whether slogging it out on the field, helping out in the canteen or just cheering on from the sidelines, the locals appreciate their footy and as the community grows, it is a great place to catch up and stay connected.

results.title: Stories from Yambuk Youth
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Five boys from Yambuk talk about what it means to be young in a small regional town and the various activities the town has to offer. They tell of the fun times growing up in the country, what they would like to change about the world and their ambitions for the future.

results.title: Sea Changers
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: More and more people are moving to Port Fairy to be part of a strong, creative and social community. We meet Katie Wise who came to Port Fairy for a visit, and has been there for 10 years now, managing the school canteen and teaching the kids the benefit of healthy food. For Helen and Ben Fennessy, Port Fairy is a place that gives them great solitude to be able to do what they like creatively. Judy and Victor Gillatt explored the town while on holiday in 1973, and the more they explored, the more they liked.

results.title: Ted: The Kite Man
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ted the kite man is a Port Fairy icon. A long time resident, Ted has a kite shop, a big heart, and a contagious philosophy as he encourages kids to explore the winds and the outdoors flying their kites. He and his partner build kites with 3,000 children a year and he believes flying a kite helps you forget all your concerns of the day while participating in this peaceful activity.

results.title: Port Fairy Connections
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Essie Warmuth introduces us to the various social, political and community groups that thrive in Port Fairy. There’s the bike group that rides every morning, rain, hail or shine. Next we go indoors to visit a book club that has entertained and engaged a group of women for over 30 years. These women have shared books, births, weddings and funerals over the years. Finally, a community action group, in collaboration with the local IGA, devoted to stamping out the use of plastic bags in Port Fairy. These groups illustrate the diverse interests of this small town as well as creating a strong sense of community for the locals.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Moyne
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, ACMI Content Development, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine stories that embrace the spirit of three towns in the Moyne region in Victoria. Through interviews with the locals and footage of the region and various events, this compilation encapsulates life in Victorian towns today, the reasons for choosing the rural life over the city, activities, concerns and the things that bind these small communities together. Filmed as part of ‘ACMI in the regions’.

Filmed as part of ‘ACMI in the regions’.
description_for_label: Nine stories that embrace the spirit of three towns in the Moyne region in Victoria. Through interviews with the locals and footage of the region and various events, this compilation encapsulates life in Victorian towns today, the reasons for choosing the rural life over the city, activities, concerns and the things that bind these small communities together. Filmed as part of ‘ACMI in the regions’.
